_exec_summary.SummaryText:
THE LUBRIZOL CORPORATION - DEER PARK PLANT, DEER PARK, TX.  77536 (07/21/2015)



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------



The Lubrizol Corporation is committed to improving the safety of our products and processes. As part of Lubrizol's philosophy, we believe in maintaining the health and safety of our employees, customers, community neighbors, and in protecting the environment.



Lubrizol's Deer Park facility was founded in 1951 and is located on 330 acres along the north side of US 225 between Patrick's Bayou and East Boulevard. The plant is staffed by about 600 full-time Lubrizol employees and about 250 contractors. Each year the plant is recognized for community involvement in such areas as Partners in Education, Junior Achievement, Texas Scholars,  D.A.R.E., Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, YMCA, YWCA, Habitat for Humanity, Boys and Girls Harbor, and numerous other charitable events. 



Lubrizol emphasizes prevention of incidents.  However, we have a very dynamic emergency preparedness program should an unexpected event occur. Lubrizol is a founding member of Channel Industries Mutual Aide (CIMA), the largest chemical plant mutual aide organization in the world.  We work closely with our Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and Community Advisory Council (CAC) and are active supporters of the American Chemistry Council's (ACC) Responsible Care program.  



Facility and Regulated Substances Handled: 

---------------------------------------------------------------



The Lubrizol Deer Park plant manufactures specialty chemical additives for lubricating oils used in gasoline and diesel engines, automatic transmissions, gear drives, marine engines and tractors. RMP covered materials include chlorine, 2- methylpropene, isobutane, propylene oxide, 1,3 butadiene, pentane, and boron trifluoride.  



Chlorine, used in our 198 and SCL-IOB/SCL prod

ucts, is received by pipeline.  Chlorine does not remain in the products except in trace amounts. 



2-Methylpropene is used by our Poly Plant, HR-PIB, and IOB/SCL units to manufacture intermediates.  2-Methylpropene is introduced to the site via pipeline to reduce on-site inventory.  Isobutane is separated from the supplied 2-methylpropene in the Poly Plant and returned to the supplier by pipeline. We have the capability to store isobutane and 2-methylpropene on site, although there is typically no stored inventory.  



The HR-PIB unit is new to our facility, and due to begin start-up activities in late 2018.  Referenced in the previous paragraph, this new unit produces a lubricant additive precursor, using 2-Methylpropene, and returns isobutane to our supplier.  



Boron Trifluoride is the catalyst for the new HR-PIB process, and is new to the Deer Park facility, although we have handled this catalyst at our Bayport plant for over 40 years.  The material is received and stored in tube trailers, and fed to the unit through a dedicated charging line, where it catalyzes the reaction, with any unconsumed catalyst then neutralized downstream of the reactor.



Propylene Oxide is used in the manufacture of passenger car motor oils, heavy-duty engine oils and automotive and industrial gear oils. It is received in rail cars and stored on-site. 



1,3-Butadiene is used in the manufacturing of extreme pressure agents and corrosion inhibitors used in gear lubricants. It is received in rail cars and fed directly to the reactor where it is totally reacted to form a less hazardous material. 



Pentane is a covered flammable used in the manufacture of marine diesel engine oils, automatic transmission fluids and other lubricating additive packages.  Lubrizol stores the material on-site.





General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------



Lubrizol's Deer Park plant emphasizes prevention of incidents while maintaining an excellent emergency response program, good cooperation with its neighboring chemical plants through CIMA, and open dialog with the community through participation in the local LEPC and CAC. Lubrizol has established direct hot lines to neighboring Shell and Oxychem plants.



Lubrizol's attention to accident prevention begins very early in the life of a product with our New Chemical Introduction Process (NCIP) that evaluates and manages all aspects of new chemical introduction from inception to production. A second process, New Chemical Issues Assessment (NCIA), ensures that pollution prevention, inherent safety, and product stewardship consideration are addressed starting at invention and continuing through development.  A Process Hazard Analysis is performed on all expansions or modifications of sufficient risk to a manufacturing process before being put into service, whether or not they are covered under OSHA PSM or EPA RMP. 



One successful strategy Lubrizol has used over the years for incident prevention is the reduction in quantity of hazardous material stored on-site.  In 1993, we significantly reduced chlorine storage by converting three chlorine storage tanks into containment tanks for a potential chlorine release. In another example, 2-methylpropene is now brought on the premises via pipeline rather than stored on-site.



For new facilities or modifications, the Deer Park plant uses generally accepted industry standards and practices. In addition, the plant has developed a multi-disciplinary set of Texas Standards for engineering, design, and construction standards and practices to be followed when industry standards and practices are not available. 



To ensure that any new facility or facility modification is constructed according to good standards and practices the plant has a contractor qualification program.  All contractor craftsmen

must receive training from the Houston Area Contractors Safety Council (HACSC). Part of the training received at the HACSC is site specific to the Lubrizol facility. 



Hot Work Permits are required before welding, brazing, or any other activity that could generate a source of ignition. The Hot Work Permit documents that fire prevention and protection have been considered prior to beginning hot work. A key component of the Hot Work Permit is the requirement to have a joint walkthrough meeting at the work site between craftsman doing the work and the operator representative authorizing the work. Permits are required for any type of hazardous work, including "Confined Space Entry", Line Breaking", and "General Work".



A Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) is conducted before any new or modified facility is put into operation.  The PSSR is a review by a multi-disciplinary team to confirm that the equipment is in accordance with design specifications and that adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place.



There are prevention programs which focus on keeping an existing operating process safe when changes are made. The Lubrizol Deer Park plant follows a formal Management of Change (MOC) procedure. The purpose of the MOC procedure is to assure that the technical basis of the change is understood and that the impact of safety and health is considered prior to the change. 



Written operating procedures for all of our processes are in place identifying safe operating limits, consequences of deviation from those limits, and corrective action to be taken in the event of a deviation. In addition, operating personnel receive training on the safe operation of their processes and are trained on process modifications, as they occur, as part of the Management of Change process. 



Inspection and testing of existing pipe and equipment are key parts of the plant's Mechanical Integrity program. Piping and equipment are periodically inspected or t

ested to assure that they meet the design specifications. If deterioration is detected, the piping or piece of equipment is repaired or replaced.  This program identifies potential failures before they occur in a proactive fashion.



An employee safety program that we feel is very effective in reducing risk is called Safety Through Employee Participation (STEP).  This is a voluntary observation and feed-back program.  The STEP program identifies many near misses. Plant safety teams will then discuss and make recommendations to resolve potential problem areas.  There is a heavy emphasis on near miss investigations to prevent safety problems from occurring.



In addition to general protection measures, several of our RMP covered materials have special safeguards to reduce the likelihood and severity of potential releases.  2-Methylpropene and isobutane are covered under monthly/quarterly fugitive emissions monitoring.  Any leaks are repaired promptly.  The Poly Plant and HR-PIB units are each equipped with a flare that would be used to flare off (burn) excess material should there be an upset condition.  



The geographic footprint of the Poly Plant is covered with a grid of 59 flammable gas detectors that alarm aurally and visually in the area of the detected event and in the main process control system.  Due to the flammability of 2-methylpropene and isobutane, the entire area is protected with deluge systems that are zoned and have individual activation points.  Fire water curtains assist in isolating the 2-methylpropene area from the rest of the plant in the event of a release, reducing the potential for an event to impact other areas.  To ensure rapid response in the event of an emergency, a single button activation emergency shutdown system has been engineered into this unit.  There is also an independent secondary shutdown mechanism for the unit.



For Boron Trifluoride, tube trailers are stored in a totally enclosed building, which is equipped with detecto

rs, alarms, and an exhaust air scrubber.  In the event of a leak or release from a trailer, the building would contain the gas, and the scrubber would remove over 95% of any Boron Trifluoride that would be in the exhausted air. 

 

For chlorine, Lubrizol follows The Chlorine Institute recommended practices for safe handling.  We have also had our chlorine supplier visit the plant site and review our handling methods.  Emergency pressure relieving devices are designed to protect equipment from over pressure by relieving into containment tanks rather than directly to the atmosphere. We have also installed expansion bottles in the chlorine line to allow for liquid thermal expansion, preventing potential line leaks.  



In units that use chlorine, operators perform a chlorine line inspection every six hours to insure there are no leaks.  In addition, these units have numerous chlorine gas detectors and alarms to detect a leak.  Several emergency shutdown stations are located throughout the processing area where, by activation of a single push button, the chlorine piping can be isolated from a leak point.  



Five Year Accident History: 

----------------------------------------



There have been no releases of EPA covered chemicals at Lubrizol's Deer Park plant in the past five years which had an adverse impact on the community.  There have also been no incidents at the facility, in the last 5 years, that triggered RMP reporting requirements.  



Emergency Response Program:

----------------------------------------------



Lubrizol emphasizes prevention of incidents, however, we have a very active Emergency Preparedness Program. Emergency response teams are available in the plant 24 hours a day. The plant has more than 100 people trained in emergency response and an additional staff of over ninety people on our emergency response paging system. Emergency response personnel at Lubrizol's Deer Park facility receive more than 6,000 aggregate hours of training annuall

y. 



In the event of an accidental release, the plant alarm system activates the Emergency Response Team to mitigate the incident.  Security through our alpha-numeric paging system, immediately sends out information to be provided to the public through our local LEPC, and uses our hotline to advise our immediate neighbors.  Training is provided throughout the year on various aspects of our emergency response program, and drills are conducted on-site, with our mutual aid organization, and our local LEPC.   Lubrizol utilizes an Incident Command System with documented emergency response procedures.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

----------------------------------------------------



Approximately 350-400 feet of underground chlorine pipeline was replaced in October 2014.  The new pipeline is equipped with cathodic protection and is capable of being pigged for proper inspection.  The project was implemented to reduce the risk of corrosion and failure due to years of exposure to humidity.



Further improvements were completed in 2015.  The relief valves in chlorine service were upgraded from conventional type to balanced bellows to prevent potential chlorine leaks.  Set pressures were increased from 170 to 200 psig to reduce the possibility of pressure spikes caused by summer heat to result in an inadvertent release.  Also, hydraulic calculations identified a need to increase the inlet line size and rupture disk on the chlorine surge drum in certain relief scenarios.  This was corrected in 2015, as well.



For our pentane handling unit, numerous minor changes have been implemented to make the unit safer.  Some flex hoses have been made lighter to improve ergonomics and others have been replaced with piping.  Nitric acid is no longer handled in drums and with portable pumps, but instead in totes and with fixed pumps.  Improved automation reduces operator physical tasks within the unit.  Extensive repairs to the pentane storage tank were implemented after a ro

utine inspection identified a corrosion under insulation concern.

 

The Deer Park facility became RCMS certified under the Responsible Care initiative of the American Chemistry Council in July 2007, and was recertified in 2010, 2013, and 2017.  We are currently working toward RC14001 certification.  The plant maintains the PHA schedule required by the PSM standard in addition to performing PHAs of non-covered processes on a select basis commensurate with risk.  These PHAs are done using a combination of HAZOP and checklist techniques.  Process operators participate in each PHA.  In addition to revalidations every five years, the plant conducts capital project PHAs for process related projects that meet certain risk criteria or are in excess of $500,000.
